item.title: REASONS FOR THE “MOOD SHIFT” BETWEEN
item.description:
REASONS FOR THE “MOOD SHIFT” BETWEEN

2 CORINTHIANS 9 AND 10

  1. Change of situation

During the process of writing, Paul received word that the situation in Corinth had taken a turn for the worse again. As a result, the rest of the letter has more of a stern character.

  1. Different letter

2 Corinthians 1-9 represents a substantial part of the fourth Corinthian correspondence, while 10-13 represents part of a lost “severe letter” written between what we know as 1 and 2 Corinthians.

item.title: RECONSTRUCTION OF THE FOURFOLD CORINTHIAN
item.description:
RECONSTRUCTION OF THE FOURFOLD CORINTHIAN

CORRESPONDENCE THEORY

2 Corinthians 6:14-7:1 does not form the whole of the “previous letter.” It is not a unit that can stand on its own, so its beginning and end have been removed and then inserted where it does not fit very well. The reasons for considering these verses an interpolation are (1) that they do not tie closely to the surrounding context and (2) that if they are omitted, the flow of thought is smooth enough that a reader would not notice anything was missing. In relation to the first reason, we wonder why a redactor would put it in at this point if it does not fit with the context very well, especially after he had excised it from its original setting in a fashion that does not form a unit. If a redactor could insert a paragraph that was loosely connected, an author himself could do the same thing.

item.title: THE “PREVIOUS LETTER” TO THE CORINTHIANS
item.description:
THE “PREVIOUS LETTER” TO THE CORINTHIANS

List of Views

A. There was no previous letter.

B. There was a previous letter.

  1. Now lost

  2. Partially included in 2 Corinthians 6:14-7:1

I. There was a Previous Letter: 1 Corinthians 5:9-13.

A. Ἔγραψα [egrapsa, “I wrote”] is a normal past-tense aorist in 5:9.

B. “My letter” (5:9) sounds like a more distant reference (literally “I-have-written/I-wrote to you in the[my] letter”; ἔγραψα ὑμῖν ἐν τῇ ἐπιστολῇ [egrapsa hymīn en tēi epistolēi]).
